questions.question_text:
A VCF administrator is preparing to configure scheduled backups for the SDDC Manager.
What must the administrator register as an external component to complete this task?

choices.B: A cluster of three large NSX edge node
choices.A: A cluster of two small NSX edge nodes
choices.D: A cluster of one large NSX edge node
choices.C: A cluster of two large NSX edge nodes

questions.question_text:
An architect needs to enable the workload management for a VCF VI workload domain and plans on using the minimum requirement for deploying a highly available NSX edge cluster.
What is the minimum requirement for this deployment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer C is Correct
NSX edge node HA required 2 nodes but small size is for PoC only, not a best answer.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T-Data-Center/3.1/installation/GUID-22F87CA8-01A9-4F2E-B7DB-9350CA60EA4E.html
Would say A because minimum requirement

choices.D: One cluster distributed across two racks and one workload domain
choices.C: One cluster stretching two workload domains
choices.F: Workload domain with multiple clusters in one rack
choices.E: Workload domain with multiple availability zones each containing clusters
choices.B: Two clusters forming one stretched workload domain
choices.A: One stretched cluster across two regions and two workload domains

comments.content: I agree. D is also a valid design, but it considers just one cluster rather than "multiple", as required in the question. Tricky wording, though.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BEF
use cases for "multiple" clusters -- other options says "one cluster"

questions.question_text: Which three options are valid use cases for multiple clusters in a workload domain? (Choose three.)

An administrator is tasked with providing additional North-South throughput to the workloads hosted on overlay-backed networks in a VI Workload Domain stretched cluster. A two-node NSX Edge cluster was previously deployed through SDDC Manager before the cluster was stretched.
Which option is valid to add two nodes to the existing edge cluster while maintaining password rotation capability?

choices.D: Expand the existing NSX Edge cluster using NSX Manager, and import the additional nodes in SDDC Manager.
choices.C: Expand the existing NSX Edge cluster using SDDC Manager, and place the additional NSX Edge nodes on a different stretched Workload Domain cluster.
choices.B: Expand the existing NSX Edge cluster using SDDC Manager, and place the additional NSX Edge nodes on the same stretched Workload Domain cluster.
choices.A: Create a new NSX Edge cluster using SDDC Manager on the same stretched Workload Domain cluster.

questions.question_text: Which two options can be used to create a new VMware Cloud Foundation VI workload domain? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Answer for me is : A & B

Selected Answer: AB
The other options are not supported for creating a new VI workload domain.

Cloud Builder UI is used to deploy VMware Cloud Foundation on a pre-existing infrastructure.
PowerCLI is a command-line tool that can be used to manage VMware Cloud Foundation.
vCenter UI is used to manage VMware vSphere.
